events: Giotto paints the Arena Chapel frescoes in Padua, revolutionizing Western art with naturalistic figures
Dante Alighieri begins writing the 'Divine Comedy', one of literature's greatest works
King Philip IV of France suppresses the Knights Templar, seizing their wealth and power
The Ottoman Empire is founded by Osman I in Anatolia, beginning centuries of expansion
Chinese Yuan Dynasty under Kublai Khan reaches its cultural and territorial peak
Development of mechanical clocks begins in Europe, transforming time measurement
The Great Famine begins in Europe, lasting until 1317 and killing millions
Dante completes 'Inferno', the first part of the Divine Comedy
Scots led by Robert the Bruce defeat the English at the Battle of Bannockburn
Pope Clement V moves the papacy to Avignon, beginning the 'Babylonian Captivity' of the Church
The Majapahit Empire forms in Java, becoming one of Southeast Asia's greatest kingdoms
Gothic architecture reaches its height with the construction of cathedrals across Europe
The Declaration of Arbroath asserts Scottish independence, influencing later democratic documents
The Avignon Papacy flourishes under Pope John XXII who reforms Church finances
Marco Polo dies, leaving behind accounts of his travels that expanded European knowledge of Asia
Ibn Battuta begins his 24-year journey across Africa, the Middle East, and Asia
Mansa Musa, ruler of Mali, makes his legendary pilgrimage to Mecca, displaying immense wealth
William of Ockham develops 'Ockham's Razor', the principle of philosophical simplicity
The Hundred Years' War begins between England and France, lasting until 1453
Petrarch climbs Mont Ventoux, symbolically marking the beginning of Renaissance humanism
The Black Death emerges in Central Asia, soon to devastate Europe and much of the world
Giotto designs the bell tower (campanile) for Florence Cathedral, a masterpiece of Gothic architecture
The Vijayanagara Empire is founded in Southern India, becoming a center of Hindu culture
Early forms of Renaissance art begin to appear in Tuscany, moving away from Medieval styles
The Black Death reaches Europe, ultimately killing 30-60% of the population
English victories at the Battles of Crécy and Sluys change medieval warfare through use of longbows
Giovanni Boccaccio writes 'The Decameron', set during the plague in Florence
Petrarch's sonnets to Laura establish the sonnet as a major poetic form in European literature
The Aztec civilization begins to flourish in the Valley of Mexico, founding Tenochtitlan
The Alhambra palace complex is completed in Granada under Islamic rule
The Black Death ends its first wave, having transformed European society and economy
The Golden Bull establishes the legal structure of the Holy Roman Empire until 1806
Corpus Christi College at Oxford is founded, focused on classical learning
The Ottoman Turks establish their first European foothold at Gallipoli
The first mechanical astronomical clock is built in Strasbourg Cathedral
Giovanni Boccaccio completes 'On Famous Women', an early work advocating women's achievements
The Treaty of Brétigny temporarily pauses the Hundred Years' War
Timur (Tamerlane) begins building his vast empire across Central Asia
Founding of the Hanseatic League, a commercial alliance of trading cities in Northern Europe
The Hongwu Emperor founds China's Ming Dynasty after overthrowing the Mongol Yuan Dynasty
Geoffrey Chaucer begins his literary career, eventually writing 'The Canterbury Tales'
Early Renaissance humanism spreads through Florence under Coluccio Salutati's influence
The Hundred Years' War resumes with renewed French success under Charles V
The Great Western Schism begins with rival popes in Rome and Avignon
Ibn Khaldun writes 'Muqaddimah', pioneering historical and sociological methodology
Construction of the Bastille fortress begins in Paris
The Kingdom of Poland and Grand Duchy of Lithuania unite, forming a major European power
John Wycliffe begins translating the Bible into English, challenging Church authority
The Peasants' Revolt erupts in England, led by Wat Tyler against poll taxes
The Battle of Kulikovo marks the beginning of Muscovite rise and Mongol decline in Russia
Chaucer begins writing 'The Canterbury Tales', a cornerstone of English literature
The University of Heidelberg is founded, becoming a center of early Renaissance learning
Wat Tyler's Rebellion in England shows growing resistance to feudal obligations after the Black Death
Filippo Brunelleschi is born in Florence, later to revolutionize architecture with the Cathedral dome
Geoffrey Chaucer completes most of 'The Canterbury Tales' before his death in 1400
The first quarantine station is established in Venice to combat plague
Richard II of England is deposed, beginning the Lancaster dynasty
Ottoman Turks begin besieging Constantinople, a process that will last decades
The Korean Joseon dynasty is founded, lasting until 1897
Early Renaissance art flourishes in Florence with artists like Lorenzo Monaco
The Renaissance accelerates in Florence under Medici patronage, emphasizing classical learning and artistic innovation
Geoffrey Chaucer, author of 'The Canterbury Tales', dies leaving his masterwork unfinished
The Inca Empire begins significant expansion under Emperor Yupanqui in South America
Owain Glyndŵr leads Welsh revolt against English rule, becoming the last native Prince of Wales
The Goryeo Dynasty in Korea is replaced by the Joseon Dynasty, lasting until 1897
Byzantine artist Theophanes the Greek creates icons and frescoes that influence Russian Orthodox art
Filippo Brunelleschi designs the dome of Florence Cathedral, solving major architectural challenges
Jan Hus, early church reformer, is burned at the stake for heresy, sparking the Hussite Wars
Henry V of England defeats the French at the Battle of Agincourt during the Hundred Years' War
Portuguese explorers begin sailing down the west coast of Africa, initiating the Age of Discovery
The Council of Constance ends the Great Western Schism by electing a single pope, Martin V
Donatello sculpts 'St. George', establishing new standards in Renaissance sculpture
The Treaty of Troyes makes Henry V of England heir to the French throne
Joan of Arc leads French forces against English occupation, turning the tide of the Hundred Years' War
Zheng He completes his seventh and final treasure voyage, expanding Chinese maritime influence
Brunelleschi demonstrates linear perspective in painting, revolutionizing visual arts
The Forbidden City is completed in Beijing, becoming the Chinese imperial palace
Early Renaissance painter Masaccio creates the Trinity fresco, demonstrating mathematical perspective
Joan of Arc is captured, tried for heresy and burned at the stake by the English and their allies
Donatello creates his bronze 'David', one of the first free-standing nude sculptures since antiquity
The Council of Basel challenges papal authority, reflecting ongoing church reform movements
Johannes Gutenberg begins experimenting with printing technology in Strasbourg
Flemish painter Jan van Eyck completes 'The Arnolfini Portrait', pioneering oil painting techniques
The empire of Mali begins its decline, weakening West African gold trade networks
Johannes Gutenberg invents the printing press with movable type, revolutionizing information sharing
The Medici family consolidates power in Florence under Cosimo de' Medici
The Kingdom of Korea introduces Hangul alphabet, increasing literacy beyond the elite
Donatello sculpts his bronze 'Judith and Holofernes', a masterpiece of early Renaissance art
Albanian national hero Skanderbeg begins resistance against Ottoman rule
Portuguese explorers reach Cape Verde and continue mapping the African coast
The Hundred Years' War ends with France regaining most territories from England
The Gutenberg Bible becomes the first major book printed with movable type in the West
The Ottoman Turks capture Constantinople, ending the Byzantine Empire and shifting European trade
Ghiberti completes the 'Gates of Paradise' bronze doors for the Florence Baptistery
Wars of the Roses begin in England between the houses of York and Lancaster
Portuguese navigator Diogo Gomes reaches the Gambia River, advancing African exploration
The Renaissance spreads throughout Italy and begins influencing Northern Europe
Mehmed II expands the Ottoman Empire into Southeastern Europe after taking Constantinople
Vlad the Impaler (inspiration for Dracula) fights the Ottomans while ruling Wallachia
Sandro Botticelli begins his career in Florence, later creating masterpieces like 'Primavera'
Sunni Ali establishes the Songhai Empire in West Africa, centered in Gao and Timbuktu
The first printed books in English appear, produced by William Caxton
The Wars of the Roses continue in England with Edward IV and the Yorkists temporarily victorious
Leonardo da Vinci begins his apprenticeship with Verrocchio in Florence
William Caxton establishes the first printing press in England
Matthias Corvinus creates a renowned library in Hungary, advancing Renaissance humanism
Sandro Botticelli paints 'The Birth of Venus', becoming an iconic Renaissance artwork
Axayacatl expands the Aztec Empire, which reaches its greatest territorial extent
The Spanish Inquisition begins under Ferdinand and Isabella, enforcing Catholic orthodoxy
Leonardo da Vinci paints 'The Virgin of the Rocks' and begins ambitious engineering projects
Ivan III (the Great) ends Mongol rule over Russia, establishing an independent Russian state
Sandro Botticelli paints 'Primavera', synthesizing classical mythology and Christian symbolism
Portuguese explorer Diogo Cão reaches the Congo River, advancing African coastal exploration
The War of Ferrara reshapes Italian politics and alliances among city-states
Christopher Columbus secures funding from Spain for his voyage seeking a western route to Asia
Leonardo da Vinci paints 'The Last Supper' in Milan, creating one of art's most famous works
Michelangelo begins his career as a sculptor, soon creating his 'Pietà' in Rome
The Signoria commissions Michelangelo's 'David' for the city of Florence
The Tudors gain the English throne after Henry VII defeats Richard III at Bosworth Field
Savonarola gains influence in Florence, leading to the 'Bonfire of the Vanities' and temporary decline of Renaissance values
Leonardo da Vinci paints the Mona Lisa, creating one of the most famous portraits in history
The first African slaves are transported to the Americas, beginning the transatlantic slave trade
Portuguese navigator Pedro Álvares Cabral discovers Brazil, expanding European presence in the Americas
Hieronymus Bosch paints 'The Garden of Earthly Delights', a complex allegorical masterpiece
The Inca Empire reaches its greatest extent under Huayna Capac
Michelangelo begins sculpting his masterpiece 'David' in Florence, completed in 1504
Michelangelo paints the Sistine Chapel ceiling, creating one of the supreme works of Western art
Martin Luther posts his 95 Theses, sparking the Protestant Reformation
Raphael paints 'The School of Athens', embodying High Renaissance ideals and humanism
The Portuguese establish Goa as their Indian trading center, expanding European colonial power
Henry VIII becomes King of England, eventually leading to the English Reformation
Nicolaus Copernicus develops his heliocentric theory, revolutionizing astronomy
Hernán Cortés conquers the Aztec Empire, dramatically altering Mesoamerican civilization
Suleiman the Magnificent becomes Ottoman Sultan, beginning the empire's golden age
Luther's translation of the New Testament makes scripture accessible to ordinary Germans
Portuguese explorer Ferdinand Magellan's expedition completes the first circumnavigation of the globe
The Field of the Cloth of Gold summit between Henry VIII and Francis I displays Renaissance royal grandeur
Mannerism emerges in European art, moving beyond High Renaissance balance toward complexity and tension
Henry VIII breaks with Rome and establishes the Church of England to annul his marriage
Francisco Pizarro conquers the Inca Empire, dramatically transforming South America
The Society of Jesus (Jesuits) is founded by Ignatius of Loyola, becoming a major Catholic force
Jacques Cartier explores the St. Lawrence River, claiming Canada for France
Michelangelo begins painting 'The Last Judgment' in the Sistine Chapel
The Portuguese establish trading posts in Japan, beginning 100 years of European-Japanese contact
Michelangelo completes 'The Last Judgment' on the Sistine Chapel altar wall
Copernicus publishes 'On the Revolutions of the Celestial Spheres', proposing heliocentrism
The Council of Trent begins, launching the Counter-Reformation against Protestantism
The Spanish establish major silver mines at Potosí in Bolivia, fueling the global economy
Titian paints 'Venus of Urbino', a masterpiece of Venetian Renaissance art
Francis Xavier begins Christian missionary work in Japan and Southeast Asia
Ivan the Terrible becomes the first Tsar of Russia, expanding and centralizing the state
The Peace of Augsburg recognizes Lutheran states in the Holy Roman Empire
Vasari publishes 'Lives of the Most Excellent Painters, Sculptors, and Architects', founding art history
The Valois-Habsburg Wars continue to reshape European power politics
The Mughals under Akbar begin conquering northern India, creating a powerful empire
Titian paints masterful late works like 'The Rape of Europa', influencing future Baroque artists
The Council of Trent concludes, solidifying Catholic doctrine against Protestant challenges
Pieter Bruegel the Elder creates 'The Hunters in the Snow' and other masterpieces of Northern Renaissance art
Elizabeth I establishes the Anglican Church as a middle way between Catholicism and radical Protestantism
The Northern Seven Years' War reshapes Baltic region politics and trade
Akbar the Great establishes a policy of religious tolerance in the Mughal Empire
Ottoman architect Sinan completes the Süleymaniye Mosque in Istanbul, a masterpiece of Islamic architecture
The Battle of Lepanto halts Ottoman naval expansion in the Mediterranean
El Greco moves to Spain, developing his distinctive elongated style that bridges Renaissance and Baroque
The Portuguese state is unified with Spain under Philip II, forming a global colonial power
The Mughal Empire under Akbar consolidates power across northern India
Francis Drake begins his circumnavigation of the globe, completed in 1580
Tycho Brahe builds Uraniborg observatory, enabling unprecedented astronomical observations
Sir Francis Drake completes his circumnavigation of the globe, bringing great wealth to England
Spanish Armada is defeated by the English, marking a shift in European naval power
The Gregorian calendar is introduced by Pope Gregory XIII, replacing the Julian calendar
Montaigne publishes his 'Essays', revolutionizing prose writing and philosophical reflection
The Colonial era accelerates with European powers establishing global trading networks
Shakespeare begins his theater career, eventually transforming Western drama and literature
Shakespeare writes his early plays including 'Romeo and Juliet' and 'A Midsummer Night's Dream'
Matteo Ricci establishes a Jesuit mission in China, beginning significant cultural exchange
Galileo Galilei develops early theories on motion that will revolutionize physics
Dutch explorers make their first voyage to the East Indies, beginning Dutch colonial expansion
Caravaggio develops his revolutionary chiaroscuro painting technique in Rome
The Nine Years' War begins in Ireland, resulting in increased English control
Caravaggio completes 'The Calling of St. Matthew', revolutionizing art with dramatic use of chiaroscuro
Giordano Bruno is burned at the stake by the Inquisition for heresy
Battle of Sekigahara in Japan establishes Tokugawa shogunate that will rule for 250+ years
The East India Company is chartered in London, beginning British commercial dominance in Asia
First performance of Shakespeare's 'Hamlet'
The Baroque art period begins across Europe, emphasizing drama, grandeur and emotional intensity
Galileo publishes 'Sidereus Nuncius', documenting his telescope observations of Jupiter's moons
Henry Hudson explores Hudson Bay in North America but is set adrift by mutineers and never seen again
Marie de Medici is appointed regent of France following assassination of King Henry IV
The Basilica of Santa Maria della Salute begins construction in Venice by architect Baldassare Longhena
Claudio Monteverdi composes 'Vespers', one of the most ambitious religious musical works of its time
Dutch painter Rubens establishes his studio in Antwerp, becoming a dominant figure in Baroque art
Pilgrims arrive at Plymouth, Massachusetts aboard the Mayflower and establish Plymouth Colony
The Battle of White Mountain marks the beginning of the Catholic Habsburg domination of Bohemia
Dutch painter Frans Hals creates 'The Laughing Cavalier', showcasing his distinctive brushwork
The Dutch West India Company is founded, instrumental in the colonization of the Americas
Francis Bacon publishes 'Novum Organum', pioneering the scientific method
Guercino paints 'Et in Arcadia Ego', an influential memento mori work that would inspire Nicolas Poussin
Puritan migration to New England begins as Massachusetts Bay Colony is established
Italian plague of 1629-1631 kills approximately one million people
Rembrandt's 'The Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Nicolaes Tulp' showcases his mastery of group portraiture
Construction begins on the Taj Mahal in Agra, India by Shah Jahan as a tomb for his wife
Johannes Kepler's 'Somnium' is published posthumously, considered the first work of science fiction
The Ming dynasty in China begins its final decline after famines and peasant revolts
The Long Parliament begins in England, challenging King Charles I's authority
Portugal rebels against Spanish rule, beginning the Portuguese Restoration War
The Bay Psalm Book becomes the first book printed in British North America
Dutch painter Vermeer begins his career, innovating with light and color techniques
Gian Lorenzo Bernini completes the baldachin in St. Peter's Basilica, Rome
Cardinal Richelieu dies in France after transforming the country into a centralized state
The Commonwealth of England is established after the execution of Charles I, with Oliver Cromwell rising to power
The Peace of Westphalia ends the Thirty Years' War, establishing new principles of international relations
Velázquez paints 'Portrait of Pope Innocent X', described by the pope as 'too truthful'
The first coffeehouse in England opens in Oxford, becoming centers of intellectual discussion
René Descartes dies in Sweden after revolutionizing philosophy with 'I think, therefore I am'
The Dutch begin colonizing the Cape of Good Hope in South Africa, establishing a trading post
The English Restoration occurs as Charles II returns from exile to reclaim the throne
The Royal Society is founded in London, becoming a major center for scientific research
Rembrandt paints 'The Syndics of the Drapers' Guild', one of his final masterpieces
The Treaty of Oliva ends the war between Sweden and Poland-Lithuania
The first public opera house opens in Venice, making the art form accessible to the paying public
Pierre Le Gros the Younger creates sculptures for the Church of the Invalides in Paris
The Hudson's Bay Company is chartered, becoming crucial to the development of Canada
Molière produces some of his greatest plays including 'Le Bourgeois Gentilhomme'
The first Stradivarius violins are crafted by Antonio Stradivari in Cremona, Italy
The Treaty of Dover creates a secret alliance between England and France
Johann Sebastian Bach is born, later becoming one of the greatest composers of all time
Japanese artist Ogata Kōrin develops distinctive decorative style combining realism and abstraction
The Great Comet of 1680 is discovered, helping Isaac Newton develop his theory of gravitation
The Pueblo Revolt successfully drives Spanish colonizers from New Mexico temporarily
The last dodo bird is killed in Mauritius, making the species extinct
Antonio Vivaldi begins composing, eventually creating 'The Four Seasons' and other masterworks
Louis XIV moves his court permanently to the Palace of Versailles, centralizing French power
Pierre Puget completes 'Milo of Crotona', a masterpiece of Baroque sculpture
The Battle of the Boyne in Ireland secures Protestant ascendancy
John Locke publishes 'Two Treatises of Government', influencing democratic thought for centuries
The Salem Witch Trials begin in Massachusetts, resulting in the execution of 20 people
Joannes Vermeer's work falls into obscurity after his death, not to be rediscovered until the 19th century
The Bank of England is established, creating a framework for modern banking
Early examples of Neoclassical architecture appear, beginning a reaction against Baroque excesses
The War of Spanish Succession begins, reshaping European power dynamics for decades
The Great Northern War starts as Russia under Peter the Great challenges Swedish dominance
The last Habsburg King of Spain, Charles II, dies, triggering competing claims to the throne
Baroque composer Antonio Vivaldi becomes violin master at the Ospedale della Pietà in Venice
The first daily newspaper, The Daily Courant, is published in London
Japanese artist Ogata Kōrin creates 'Red and White Plum Blossoms', a masterpiece of the Rinpa School
The Baroque period reaches its peak across Europe in music, art, and architecture
The Meissen factory in Germany produces the first European hard-paste porcelain
J.S. Bach composes the Brandenburg Concertos, masterpieces of Baroque music
The Treaty of Utrecht ends the War of Spanish Succession, redistributing colonial territories
Daniel Defoe publishes 'Robinson Crusoe', often considered the first English novel
The South Sea Bubble financial crisis devastates investors in England after wild speculation
Johann Sebastian Bach composes his 'Well-Tempered Clavier', revolutionizing keyboard music
Peter the Great transforms Russia into a major European power, founding Saint Petersburg
The Rococo style emerges in France, characterized by light colors and playful, ornate designs
Daniel Gabriel Fahrenheit invents the mercury thermometer with a standardized scale
Composer Antonio Vivaldi publishes 'The Four Seasons', his most famous work
Jonathan Swift publishes 'Gulliver's Travels', a pioneering work of satirical literature
The Great Awakening religious revival begins in America, transforming colonial religious life
Frederick the Great becomes King of Prussia, beginning its rise as a European power
The Baroque era gradually gives way to Rococo in European art and architecture
John Kay invents the flying shuttle, revolutionizing textile production and starting the Industrial Revolution
Handel composes 'Messiah', which becomes one of the most famous oratorios in history
The founding of the Royal Opera House in Covent Garden, London establishes a new cultural center
The War of Austrian Succession begins, involving most European powers in dynastic conflict
Frederick the Great leads Prussia's rise as a military power, successfully invading Silesia
Samuel Richardson publishes 'Pamela', helping establish the modern novel form
Enlightenment ideas spread throughout Europe, challenging traditional authority
Benjamin Franklin conducts his famous kite experiment, advancing understanding of electricity
Johann Sebastian Bach composes 'The Art of Fugue', demonstrating his contrapuntal mastery
The Enlightenment reaches its height with Diderot and d'Alembert's Encyclopedia publication beginning
The Seven Years' War (1756-63) erupts across multiple continents, considered the first 'world war'
Neoclassicism emerges in art and architecture, inspired by excavations at Pompeii and Herculaneum
Jean-Jacques Rousseau publishes 'The Social Contract', influencing democratic thought
The British East India Company gains control of Bengal after the Battle of Plassey
Voltaire publishes 'Candide', satirizing optimism and established authority
The Industrial Revolution accelerates in Britain with mechanical innovations in textile production
The Treaty of Paris ends the Seven Years' War, significantly expanding British colonial territory
Catherine the Great seizes power in Russia and begins modernizing the empire
Mozart, at age six, begins performing throughout Europe, displaying his prodigious musical talent
James Watt improves the steam engine, powering the emerging Industrial Revolution
Jean-Antoine Houdon creates Neoclassical sculptural masterpieces in France
James Cook charts the eastern coastline of Australia, claiming it for Great Britain
The Boston Massacre escalates tensions between American colonists and British authorities
The American Revolution begins with the Battles of Lexington and Concord
Ludwig van Beethoven begins his musical training, eventually bridging Classical and Romantic periods
Adam Smith publishes 'The Wealth of Nations', establishing modern economic theory
Jacques-Louis David pioneers Neoclassical painting in France with historical subjects
The American Revolutionary War concludes with British recognition of American independence
Mozart composes 'The Marriage of Figaro' and other mature masterpieces
The Constitutional Convention drafts the United States Constitution in Philadelphia
Antoine Lavoisier publishes 'Elements of Chemistry', transforming chemical science
British colonization of Australia begins with the First Fleet arriving at Botany Bay
The French Revolution begins with the storming of the Bastille
The French Revolution radically transforms France's political and social structure
Mozart composes 'The Magic Flute' and his 'Requiem' before his early death
The United States Bill of Rights is ratified, guaranteeing fundamental civil liberties
Mary Wollstonecraft publishes 'A Vindication of the Rights of Woman', pioneering feminist philosophy
Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette are executed during the Reign of Terror in France
Francisco Goya begins his career as Spanish court painter while developing his personal artistic vision
Napoleon Bonaparte rises to power in France, crowning himself Emperor in 1804
Ludwig van Beethoven composes his groundbreaking Symphony No. 3 'Eroica'
The Louisiana Purchase doubles the size of the United States
Romantic movement emerges across Europe in literature, art, and music, emphasizing emotion and individualism
The Rosetta Stone is discovered, eventually enabling the decipherment of Egyptian hieroglyphics
Francisco Goya paints 'The Third of May 1808', a powerful anti-war masterpiece
Latin American independence movements accelerate under Simón Bolívar and José de San Martín
The War of 1812 between the United States and Great Britain tests American sovereignty
Napoleon is defeated at Waterloo, ending the Napoleonic Wars and reshaping Europe
Jane Austen publishes 'Pride and Prejudice', revolutionizing the novel of manners
The Congress of Vienna reestablishes European boundaries after the Napoleonic Wars
Mary Shelley writes 'Frankenstein', pioneering the science fiction genre
The Greek War of Independence begins against the Ottoman Empire
The Monroe Doctrine establishes American opposition to European colonialism in the Americas
Beethoven composes his Ninth Symphony while completely deaf
Eugène Delacroix paints 'Liberty Leading the People', an iconic Romantic masterpiece
The first railway for passenger service opens in England, revolutionizing transportation
Michael Faraday discovers electromagnetic induction, leading to electric generators
The July Revolution in France replaces Charles X with the 'Citizen King' Louis-Philippe
The Indian Removal Act forces Native American tribes to relocate west of the Mississippi River
Charles Darwin embarks on his voyage aboard HMS Beagle, gathering evidence for evolution
Britain abolishes slavery throughout its empire, affecting colonies worldwide
The Romantic movement reaches its peak in music, literature, and painting
Samuel Morse invents the telegraph, revolutionizing long-distance communication
The Opium War forces China to open ports to foreign trade, beginning its 'century of humiliation'
The Irish Potato Famine causes mass starvation and emigration
Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels publish 'The Communist Manifesto'
The California Gold Rush begins, accelerating American westward expansion
Revolutions of 1848 sweep across Europe, challenging monarchical power
Photography emerges as an art form with early daguerreotypes capturing public imagination
The Crimean War pits Russia against an alliance of Britain, France, and the Ottoman Empire
Commodore Matthew Perry forces Japan to open to foreign trade after 200 years of isolation
Gustave Courbet pioneers Realism in art, rejecting Romantic idealism
Charles Dickens publishes 'Bleak House' and other socially conscious novels
Florence Nightingale revolutionizes nursing practices during the Crimean War
Darwin continues developing his theory of evolution, later published in 'On the Origin of Species'
The American Civil War begins, eventually leading to the abolition of slavery
Charles Darwin publishes 'On the Origin of Species', revolutionizing biological understanding
Victor Emmanuel II becomes the first king of a unified Italy after centuries of division
Édouard Manet paints 'Olympia' and 'Déjeuner sur l'herbe', challenging artistic conventions
The Meiji Restoration begins in Japan, rapidly modernizing and industrializing the country
The Suez Canal opens, dramatically shortening the sea route between Europe and Asia
The Franco-Prussian War leads to German unification under Prussian leadership
The Third French Republic is established after the fall of Napoleon III
Impressionism emerges with the first exhibition including works by Monet, Renoir, and Degas
Alexander Graham Bell patents the telephone, revolutionizing communication
The Compromise of 1877 ends Reconstruction in the American South
Thomas Edison invents the phonograph, beginning the era of recorded sound
The Berlin Conference divides Africa among European colonial powers
Vincent van Gogh develops his distinctive post-impressionist style in France
The first skyscrapers are built in Chicago using steel-frame construction
Friedrich Nietzsche writes 'Thus Spoke Zarathustra', challenging traditional philosophical values
The first rabies vaccine is developed by Louis Pasteur, advancing medical science
The Washington Monument is completed, becoming the world's tallest structure at the time
The Wounded Knee Massacre marks the end of the American Indian Wars
Vincent van Gogh dies after creating his final masterpieces including 'Starry Night'
Ellis Island opens as the main immigration station for the United States
The Impressionist movement evolves into Post-Impressionism, Symbolism, and Art Nouveau
Wilhelm Röntgen discovers X-rays, revolutionizing medical diagnosis
The Dreyfus Affair divides French society, highlighting antisemitism in Europe
